analyzeResult.content:
KWAZULU-NATAL PROVINCE SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT REPUBLIC OF SOUTH AFRICA
DIRECTORATE:
Private Bag X9144, PIETERMARITZBURG, 3200 205 Pietermaritz Street, Pietermaritzburg, 3200 Enquiries: Mr Vukani Mbhele Email Address: vukani.mbhele@kzndsd.gov.za Tel: 033 348 5579
Communication Services and Stakeholder Management
20 April 2021
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
MEC KHOZA CALLS ON PARENTS TO TAKE PART IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THEIR CHILDREN
In an aim to bridge the gap between urban and rural children, KwaZulu-Natal government will continue to roll out mobile Early Child Development (ECD) centres across the province, said MEC for Social Development, Mrs Nonhlanhla Khoza.
MEC Khoza was speaking at Sibhongweni Sportsground, during the official hangover of the Mobile ECD to provide services to children in Manaba area, Wards 15 and 07 of Umhlabuyalinga Local Municipality on the far northern parts of the province.
She said it was imperative for parents to show interests in their children developments, to improve relationships with them and ensure their development at an early age.
She said government had resolved that no children should not attend ECD centres in the province.
"The ECDs are safe for our children. The Department of Social Development has a mandate to ensure safety of children, but we cannot do that alone, hence we call on all parents to take a keen interest in their children's well-being," she said.
Over 137 children will benefit from the state of the art mobile ECD, which is fitted with educational materials, toys, kitchen and a bathroom. Children will also be provided with nutritious food to help mitigate under- nourishment and stunting so that they can go through all developmental stages accordingly.
MEC Khoza said the parents would be expecting to drop their children at the facility twice a week in order to be prepared for next phase of their lives.
"The Department intends rolling out these ECDs, especially in rural areas and in farming communities. We want to ensure cognitive stimulation of children in their first 1 000 days. ECDs are important facilities that the Department brings to communities. In some areas, we have been able to build ECDs together with our stakeholders. However, those ECDs are found to be very far to some communities. We ddon't want children to travel long distances, hence we introduced mobile ECDs so that no child will be left out, even in rural areas. Our government wants to have a footprint everywhere when it comes to bringing such services to the children," she added.
MEC Khoza said stimulation of children's minds and physically was to ensure their readiness to start school. She said teachers often don't encounter challenges with children who have gone through ECDs.
She said the Department aimed to ensure that parents also played their role in the stimulation of their children and understand the importance of ECD services. The Department has spent over R1.1 million on procurement of the mobile ECD and employment of staff.
MEC Khoza also cited that all those who will be working with children in the ECD will be screened if they had no criminal records.
"We do that because we cannot afford to have people looking after children while they have criminal records. We have a team of social workers who are also attached to work with this ECD and are expected to conduct home visit. We expect the social workers to understand the home circumstances of the children so that whatever challenges they are faced with could be dealt with holistically."
The programme is a collaborative effort with sister Departments which will provide integrated services, which include Health, for health services, Education for Curriculum Development and Training of ECD Practitioners, Arts and Culture for Library toys, Sport and Recreation for play groups, Agriculture for One Creche, One Garden and COGTA for assessment of infrastructure for purposes of registration of ECD Centres as Partial Care Facilities.
Speaker of Umhlabuyalinga Local Municipality, Councillor Busisiwe Tembe, applauded MEC Khoza and the Department for bringing such a facility in the area.
"We are grateful that our government remains committed to changing the lives of the people. We are going to ensure that this ECD continues to operate. It is in the interest of parents to ensure that this this resource is properly looked after for the sake of their children."
ISSUED BY THE KWAZULU-NATAL DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT
